definition: coward
gall bladder/courage/guts/gall/inner container (e.g. bladder of a football, inner container of a thermos)
small/tiny/few/young
ghost/demon/terrible/damnable/clever/sly/crafty/(suffix for sb with a certain vice or addiction etc)/one of the 28 constellations

sentences.english: You're just a couple of skinny-armed chickens.
sentences.chinese: 你們不過是兩個細胳膊細腿的膽小鬼。

sentences.english: Cowards call themselves cautious and misers thrifty.
sentences.chinese: 膽小鬼說自己謹慎，守財奴稱自己節儉。

sentences.english: “You are a coward,” Mr. Brown cried out.
sentences.chinese: 布朗先生喊到，“你是個膽小鬼。”

sentences.english: He was the most timorous person in that event.
sentences.chinese: 在那次事件中他是個膽小鬼。

sentences.english: Kill off the Goddamned cowards and we will have a nation of brave men.
sentences.chinese: 幹掉所有狗日的膽小鬼，我們的國家將是勇士的天下。

sentences.english: Thee coward was backing, his face being deathly pale, toward another room.
sentences.chinese: 那個膽小鬼向另一個房間退去，臉色煞白。

sentences.english: Gary sure is a chicken-livered guy.
You are nothing but a big coward.
sentences.chinese: 百獸之王不應該是一個膽小鬼，”稻草人說。

sentences.english: Tom was a fraidy-cat and wouldn't go in the water.
sentences.chinese: 湯姆是個膽小鬼，不會下水去的。
爸爸是個沒骨頭的膽小鬼。

sentences.english: That coward ratted on his fellow-workers.
sentences.chinese: 那個膽小鬼告發了和他一起幹活的工人。

sentences.english: With all his boasting, he is a coward.
sentences.chinese: 儘管他大吹大擂，但他還是個膽小鬼。

sentences.english: You could be brillant, but you're coward.
sentences.chinese: 你可以很出色，但是你是個膽小鬼。

sentences.english: The recruits rushed into battle so that no one could gibe at them for cowardice.
sentences.chinese: 爲了不被別人嘲笑爲膽小鬼，新兵們衝進了戰場。

sentences.english: Many would be cowards if they had courage enough.
sentences.chinese: 許多人都是膽小鬼，只是沒勇氣承認。

definition: traitor to one's love/heartless rat
conventional greeting/polite formula
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
lit. to hate iron for not becoming steel/to feel resentful towards sb for failing to meet expectations and impatient to see improvement (idiom)
sneering/sarcasm/cynical remarks
alarm (e.g. burglar or fire alarm)/warning device
to act stupid/to play dumb/to pretend to not know
reckless/extremely daring
to play dirty tricks/to be up to mischief
crybaby
lit. either the fish dies or the net splits/a life and death struggle (idiom)
ashamed and resentful/indignant
chicken-hearted (idiom)/gutless
bastard/scoundrel/rogue
lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
lit. wind past your ear/fig. sth you don't pay much attention to/in one ear and out the other
